issues.description: The problem statement (text) refers to a method named get_total_number_of_students() using snake_case (line 40), while the UML, task names, template TODO comments, and the solution use the camelCase name getTotalNumberOfStudents(). This inconsistency in the method identifier can confuse students about the exact method name they must implement and may lead to failing tests or mismatches with the provided template/tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the problem statement to use the camelCase method name getTotalNumberOfStudents() (matching the UML, template comments, tests and solution). For example, replace get_total_number_of_students() with getTotalNumberOfStudents() to avoid ambiguity.

issues.description: The problem statement (line 40) refers to a method using snake_case: get_total_number_of_students(). However, the UML in the same problem statement, the template comments, and the solution implementation consistently use the camelCase name getTotalNumberOfStudents(). This intra- and cross-artifact naming mismatch (snake_case vs. camelCase) can confuse students about the exact method name to implement in Java (and may cause failing tests expecting the camelCase name).
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the method name across all artifacts. Replace the snake_case reference in the problem statement (get_total_number_of_students()) with the camelCase form used in code: getTotalNumberOfStudents(). Alternatively, explicitly state that the expected Java method name is getTotalNumberOfStudents() to avoid ambiguity.
